quiz.title: Unit 3, Quiz 1: Aggregate Demand and Supply
quiz.subtitle: AP Macroeconomics – Foundations of AD/AS and Short‑Run Macro Equilibrium
quiz.subject: AP Macroeconomics
quiz.topic: Aggregate Demand, Aggregate Supply, Short‑Run Equilibrium, Macroeconomic Shocks

questions.question: Which of the following would cause a rightward shift of the Aggregate Demand (AD) curve?
options: A decrease in government spending
An increase in consumer confidence
A rise in the price level
A decrease in the money supply
questions.explanation: Higher consumer confidence increases consumption spending (C), shifting AD to the right. The price level movement causes movement along the AD curve, not a shift.

questions.question: Which component of Aggregate Demand is typically the largest in a developed economy?
options: Net Exports
Government Spending
Investment
Consumption
questions.explanation: Consumption (C) is usually the largest component of GDP in advanced economies, often accounting for 60‑70% of total spending.

questions.question: The short‑run Aggregate Supply (SRAS) curve is upward sloping primarily because:
options: Input prices adjust instantly to changes in the price level
Wages and other input prices are sticky in the short run
In the long run, all prices are flexible
Potential output changes with the price level
questions.explanation: SRAS slopes upward because nominal wages and some input prices are slow to adjust (sticky). When output prices rise, real production costs fall temporarily, encouraging more output.

questions.question: Which of the following would shift the SRAS curve to the left?
options: A technological improvement
A decrease in nominal wages
An increase in the price of imported oil
A decrease in business taxes
questions.explanation: Higher input costs (e.g., imported oil) raise production costs, reducing SRAS at every price level — a leftward shift.

questions.question: If the economy is in a recessionary gap, which of the following describes the relationship between actual output and potential output?
options: Actual output is greater than potential output
Actual output equals potential output
Actual output is less than potential output
Potential output is undefined in the short run
questions.explanation: A recessionary gap occurs when actual real GDP is below potential GDP (full‑employment output).

questions.question: What would be the short‑run effect of a significant increase in business confidence on the price level and real GDP?
options: Price level increases, real GDP decreases
Price level decreases, real GDP increases
Price level increases, real GDP increases
Price level decreases, real GDP decreases
questions.explanation: Increased business confidence raises investment (I), shifting AD rightward. In the short run, this raises both real output and the price level.

questions.question: The long‑run Aggregate Supply (LRAS) curve is vertical because:
options: In the long run, only the price level matters for output
Output in the long run is determined by technology, resources, and institutions, not the price level
Government spending always adjusts to maintain full employment
The economy always returns to the natural rate of unemployment immediately
questions.explanation: LRAS is vertical at potential GDP, which depends on the economy's productive capacity (labor, capital, technology). In the long run, changes in the price level do not affect real output.

questions.question: Stagflation occurs when:
options: Both inflation and unemployment decrease
Inflation decreases but unemployment increases
Both inflation and unemployment increase
Inflation increases but unemployment decreases
questions.explanation: Stagflation = stagnation (high unemployment) + inflation. It is typically caused by a leftward shift of SRAS (e.g., supply shock).

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of a demand shock?
options: A sudden increase in oil prices
A major technological breakthrough
A large decrease in consumer spending due to a recession scare
An increase in minimum wage legislation
questions.explanation: A demand shock affects spending components of AD. A fall in consumer spending shifts AD left.

questions.question: If the economy is at full employment and there is an increase in Aggregate Demand, what is the long‑run result?
options: Higher output and higher price level
Higher output with no change in price level
No change in output, higher price level
No change in output, lower price level
questions.explanation: Starting at full employment, an AD increase raises prices in the short run but not output. In the long run, wages adjust, SRAS shifts left, returning output to potential but at a higher price level.

questions.question: A negative supply shock will most likely cause:
options: A decrease in both inflation and unemployment
An increase in inflation and a decrease in unemployment
A decrease in inflation and an increase in unemployment
An increase in both inflation and unemployment
questions.explanation: A negative supply shock (e.g., oil price spike) shifts SRAS left, raising prices (inflation) and reducing output (higher unemployment) — stagflation.

questions.question: The wealth effect, interest‑rate effect, and exchange‑rate effect explain why:
options: SRAS slopes upward
AD slopes downward
LRAS is vertical
Government spending affects output more than prices
questions.explanation: These three effects explain the inverse relationship between the price level and quantity of real GDP demanded — the downward slope of the AD curve.

questions.question: In the AD‑AS model, an inflationary gap exists when:
options: Actual GDP is less than potential GDP
Actual GDP equals potential GDP
Actual GDP is greater than potential GDP
The price level is falling
questions.explanation: An inflationary gap occurs when actual output exceeds potential output, putting upward pressure on prices.

questions.question: Which policy would be most appropriate to close a recessionary gap?
options: Increase taxes
Decrease government spending
Increase government spending
Reduce the money supply
questions.explanation: Expansionary fiscal policy (increase G or decrease T) shifts AD rightward, raising output toward potential.

questions.question: If households decide to save more and spend less, the immediate effect in the AD‑AS model is:
options: AD shifts right
AD shifts left
SRAS shifts left
LRAS shifts left
questions.explanation: Lower consumption (C) reduces aggregate demand, shifting AD left.

questions.question: The natural rate of unemployment is represented in the AD‑AS model by:
options: The vertical LRAS curve
The horizontal portion of SRAS
The point where AD intersects SRAS
The difference between actual and potential GDP
questions.explanation: LRAS corresponds to potential GDP, where the economy is at the natural rate of unemployment.

questions.question: If the government cuts taxes for households, what is the most likely short‑run effect on the AD‑AS graph?
options: AD shifts left, price level falls, output falls
AD shifts right, price level rises, output rises
SRAS shifts right, price level falls, output rises
LRAS shifts right, price level falls, output rises
questions.explanation: Tax cuts increase disposable income, raising consumption (C) and shifting AD right. In the short run, output and price level increase.

questions.question: Which scenario would cause both AD and SRAS to shift to the right?
options: A decrease in consumer confidence and a decrease in oil prices
An increase in government spending and an increase in wages
An increase in exports and a technological improvement
A decrease in taxes and an increase in business regulations
questions.explanation: Higher exports shift AD right; technological improvement shifts SRAS right.

questions.question: In the long run, after an increase in AD starting from full employment, the economy returns to:
options: A higher output level and a higher price level
The original output level and a higher price level
A higher output level and the original price level
The original output and price levels
questions.explanation: In the long run, output returns to potential (original output level), but the price level remains higher due to the initial AD increase.

questions.question: When the economy self‑corrects from a recessionary gap without policy intervention, which of the following occurs?
options: Nominal wages rise, shifting SRAS left
Nominal wages fall, shifting SRAS right
Consumer confidence rises, shifting AD right
Government spending increases, shifting AD right
questions.explanation: In a recession, unemployment puts downward pressure on wages. Lower wages reduce production costs, shifting SRAS right until output returns to potential.

scoreMessages.90: Masterful grasp of AD/AS shifts, short‑run vs. long‑run effects, gaps, and self‑correction mechanisms.
scoreMessages.70: Solid understanding; review the slope of SRAS, causes of shifts, and distinguishing demand vs. supply shocks.
scoreMessages.50: Needs focus on AD components, SRAS/LRAS differences, inflationary/recessionary gaps, and policy effects.
scoreMessages.0: Revisit: AD curve components, SRAS stickiness, LRAS determinants, and the AD‑AS equilibrium process.
